repnme.cdata!:
Guatemala - Secondary and Regional Road
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was
            satisfactory, with a highly likely sustainability, and high
            institutional development impacts. Key lessons underline
            primarily, the timing issue regarding the impacts of
            institutional reforms, vs. physical investments, i.e., that
            increased traffic volumes are even higher than expected,
            while, the results of institutional reforms, as expected,
            are taking time, as the proposed changes need acceptance,
            and understanding in its application. But although slower in
            taking effect, results are increasingly steady. This extent
            of government, and upper level management control in the
            implementation of institutional changes, is partly
            reaffirmed by the evidence that attempts to improve, or
            modify current processes, required the total support of the
            authorities, be it for facilitating new standards, for
            identifying strategies, or adequate policies for action, or
            even in attempting to minimize negative effects in
            procedural changes. Nonetheless, outsourcing road
            maintenance work to the private sector, and improvements in
            the administration of the road network, proved not only
            successful, but conducive to the rapid increase of paved
            network in good conditions.

5078642.trustfund:
TF036250-LAC REGION  - TRANSPORT SECTOR
            (HONDURAS, COSTA RICA, GUATEMALA),TF034745-GUATEMALA - RURAL AND MAIN

5078642.majtheme: Trade and integration,Rural development,Social protection and risk management

repnme.cdata!:
Guatemala - Secondary and Regional Road
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project consists of an investment
            component to be financed under the loan, and of an
            institutional development Action Plan. As such, the project
            will comprise the following components : (i) civil works for
            the rehabilitation and improvement of secondary earth roads
            nationwide and paved roads in the Antiplano region,
            including consultant services for the associated
            construction supervision; (ii) construction of labor
            intensive small bridges for the secondary and tertiary road
            network; and (iii) provision of road maintenance, training
            and miscellaneous equipment. Further to this, the project
            will finance a training program for road staff and technical
            assistance and studies. Under the Action Plan, the project
            will assist in the improvement of the efficiency of the
            highway subsector institutions; and in the strengthening of
            transport management and policy making.

Guatemala - Secondary and Regional Road
